bestBHT.bht: The violent response of the tenants in the parable when the servants were sent to collect the owner's portion of the fruit is depicted as beating some and killing some. The original meaning of the Greek word for beating had connotations of to skin, flay, indicating the severity of the violence inflicted. The word choice for killing suggests a thorough eradication. This portrayal underscores the intense hostility and resistance faced by those faithfully serving God, serving as a reminder of the trials and persecutions endured in discipleship.

Archibald T. Robertson: Originally δερω in Homer meant to skin, flay, then to smite, to beat.
Αποκτεννυντες is a μ form of the verb (αποκτεννυμ) and means to kill off.
John Gill: Many others... beating some; and killing some...

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, we are told that the owner of the vineyard sent his servants to collect his portion of the fruit, but instead of receiving it peacefully, the tenants responded with violence, beating some and killing some. The Greek word used for beating originally meant to skin or flay, indicating the severity of the violence inflicted on some of the servants. The word used for killing signifies not just killing but killing off, emphasizing the thoroughness and number of those who were killed. This highlights the great resistance and hostility displayed by the tenants towards the owner and his servants.

The owner of the vineyard sent his servants to collect his portion of the fruit, but the tenants responded with violence, beating some and killing some. The severe violence, described as to skin, flay and kill off, demonstrates the relentless hostility and resistance exhibited by the tenants towards the owner and his servants. This vividly portrays the intense opposition faced by those who faithfully serve the Lord, reminding us to be prepared for opposition and persecution in our own lives of discipleship.

When the owner of the vineyard sent his servants to collect his portion of the fruit, the tenants responded with brutality, beating some and killing some. The original meaning of the Greek word for beating highlights the severity of the violence, akin to skinning or flaying. The term for killing signifies a thorough eradication. This depiction underscores the fierce opposition and hostility shown by the tenants towards the owner and his servants. It serves as a reminder that faithful discipleship often involves enduring persecution and opposition.

The servants sent by the owner of the vineyard were met with brutal resistance from the tenants, who engaged in acts of violence including beating and killing. The Greek word for beating originally meant to skin or flay, emphasizing the severity of the violence inflicted upon some of the servants. The term killing off implies a comprehensive eradication. This verse vividly portrays the intense hostility and opposition faced by those who faithfully serve the Lord, reminding us to be prepared for persecution in our own lives of discipleship.

The violent response of the tenants in the parable when the servants were sent to collect the owner's portion of the fruit is depicted as beating some and killing some. The original meaning of the Greek word for beating had connotations of to skin, flay, indicating the severity of the violence inflicted. The word choice for killing suggests a thorough eradication. This portrayal underscores the intense hostility and resistance faced by those faithfully serving God, serving as a reminder of the trials and persecutions endured in discipleship.
